awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Flow-Induced Crystallization for Advanced Plastics Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award supports fundamental research to deliver essential knowledge that will significantly improve the predictive modeling of the injection molding process for engineering plastics. Modern technical applications demand plastic components that can withstand extreme conditions, display critical dimensional stability or undergo predictable biodegradation. It is well known that these important properties can be significantly affected by manufacturing conditions.  To ensure the production of a robust component, simulation models are used to optimize processing. However, current simulations cannot accurately predict the properties of a plastic component created during manufacturing.  As a result, time-consuming and expensive trials are needed to prepare for manufacturing.  Improving these process models requires new knowledge in the field of polymer crystallization that will be delivered through this interdisciplinary research program.  Improved simulation models will reduce lead time in domestic manufacturing processes, resulting in benefits for the U.S. economy and society.  The program is designed for rapid dissemination of results into the industrial community, and underrepresented groups engaged herein are provided the opportunity to develop technical skills while interfacing with both academic and industrial scientists.

This award supports the first known effort to establish the cooling-rate dependence of shear induced crystallization kinetics, an important missing link required to model polymer flow and solidification.   Through a novel combination of rheological and ultra-fast calorimetric techniques, the research will establish the crystallization kinetics that result from crystalline precursors formed under shear. Ultrafast calorimetry will accurately mimic the thermal conditions under which injection molded polymer microstructures are formed.  The resulting critical kinetic data will be used to develop the fundamental understanding that will enable improvements in current crystallization models, while the accurate material-specific data will drive these models. The research will establish the crystallization behavior of flow-induced precursors without forfeiting the process history of the melt, a loss that cannot be avoided using conventional research methods that are three orders of magnitude too slow to suppress the extremely rapid polymer reorganization.  Through collaborative efforts, resulting models will be incorporated into commercial polymer flow simulation software, which will provide a much more robust model for manufacturing process simulation than is currently available.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Penn State Erie, The Behrend College

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Overview:  The primary objective of this research program was to develop a step-change improvement in the understanding of flow-enhanced nucleation and crystallization in polymer melts in part through considering, for the first time, heating and cooling rates that are on the timescale of polymer processing (up to 5000 K/second).  To date, the research has revealed crystallization behaviors previously undiscovered such as the mechanistic competition between flow and particulate-driven nucleation.  

Flash DSC (FSC) techniques allow rapid heating and cooling of polymers. The technique allows for direct thermal analysis, but also empowers polymer scientists to precisely control the crystallization pathway during solidification, and the resulting sample can be used for further analysis, essentially employing the FSC technique for both data acquisition as well as sample preparation.  This research has enabled robust methods development that begins with controlled shear flow (rheology) followed by thermal conditioning at high heating/cooling rates (FSC), followed yet again by subsequent analysis using X-ray analysis, atomic force microscopy, FT-Infrared microscopy, and/or electron microscopy.  It is now possible to observe crystallization behaviors that are directly related to conditions encountered in plastics manufacturing operations and relate bulk property development to direct microstructure evolution. Undergraduate researchers collaborated directly with industrial and academic partners and knowledge was communicated to engineers in the aerospace, automotive and medical industries to immediately influence part designs, yielding microstructure for optimized properties in strength, safety, and biodegradation.

Intellectual MERIT:  Coupling the development of fast-calorimetry techniques with careful rheological and subsequent methods, this program evaluated a series of polymers with increasing backbone stiffness and enthalpic interactions, providing insight to the importance of chain architecture to drive the mechanism of flow-induced crystallization.  In many cases a flow-induced nematic phase was identified prior to flow induced crystallization, and the flow-induced structures displayed a thermal and shear stability beyond those observed in typical lamellar crystalline structures of the same polymer.

In addition to confirming our hypothesis that flow induced precursors developed under shear in the melt have sufficient stability to nucleate subsequent crystallization events, provided that the temperature of the melt does not exceed the equilibrium melting temperature, the program developed a working understanding of the thermodynamic and kinetic drivers that cause a polymer to preferentially form a specific type of crystalline phase or microstructure. Bulk properties are driven by microstructure that evolves with specific shear work, which means that the resulting polymer crystalline polymorph, lamellar thickness, and other microstructural characteristics change with melt flow history.  This is important because the properties of everyday items, from the simple plastic fork to the complex drug-eluting polymer stent used in heart surgery, are optimized though control of the shear flow energy and the resulting microstructure.  If this melt flow is not properly controlled, products can fail prematurely and potentially cause great harm in more advanced applications.

Oftentimes these advanced applications employ high-temperature engineering thermoplastic that contain fibers or other additives for property enhancement.  For example, many high-end bearings contain glass filled poly (ether ether keytone) (PEEK).  During this program PEEK was systematically investigated using the methods developed for unfilled polymers. In this work, found that the glass fiber plays a different role under quiescent and shearing conditions during the PEEK crystallization. The quiescent crystallization data collected by FSC suggest glass fiber slows down the crystallization of PEEK, whereas under shearing conditions, once the applied work exceeded the critical applied work, glass loading accelerates the crystallization of PEEK instead of slowing it down.  Ongoing research will help to elucidate the mechanism behind the acceleration; but the hypothesis is that glass fibers help to orient the polymer in a local shear field induced between the glass fiber and polymer surfaces.  To date, the most impactful result is perhaps the discovery of the sensitivity of polymers to different levels of shearing work across the entire melt temperature range was explained and a new method for evaluating shear-induced crystallization was introduced into the scientific community.

broader IMPACTS: The program also supported our “Next Steps in Stem” program.  The annual programs were capped at ten students each year specifically so that our team could develop strong relationships and have a meaningful experience with each girl in attendance. Of the 36 students engaged during the four years of programming, 12 of these girls have elected to attend Penn State Behrend or another Penn State campus.  Fourteen of these students are yet to graduate high school, and so our final impacts are yet unknown.  In addition, ten REU students were supported and each went on to either graduate school or meaningful, related employment.  Ongoing discussions with commercial polymer melt processing simulation companies indicate the long-term commercial potential for the program results, and two industrially-sponsored research programs have already been funded to continue this work and facilitate rapid transfer of results to industrial processing.

 


Last Modified: 12/05/2023
Modified by: Alicyn M Rhoades

Image
  • a) Flow-induced crystalline structure in polyamide 66 (scale = 300 micron, width of image), b) zero-shear lamellar semicrystalline polyamide 66 (same scale), c) melt flow simulation of melt processed tensile bar used for shear rate range determination and d) POM image of sheared PA66 on FSC sensor.
    A. Rhoades
    Public Domain
    Alicyn M Rhoades
    Polarized Light and Simulation of Flow Induced Crystallization

Addendum # 1

Overview:  The primary objective of this research program was to develop a step-change improvement in the understanding of flow-enhanced nucleation and crystallization in polymer melts in part through considering, for the first time, heating and cooling rates that are on the timescale of polymer processing (up to 5000 K/second).  To date, the research has revealed crystallization behaviors previously undiscovered such as the mechanistic competition between flow and particulate-driven nucleation.  

Flash DSC (FSC) techniques allow rapid heating and cooling of polymers. The technique allows for direct thermal analysis, but also empowers polymer scientists to precisely control the crystallization pathway during solidification, and the resulting sample can be used for further analysis, essentially employing the FSC technique for both data acquisition as well as sample preparation.  This research has enabled robust methods development that begins with controlled shear flow (rheology) followed by thermal conditioning at high heating/cooling rates (FSC), followed yet again by subsequent analysis using X-ray analysis, atomic force microscopy, FT-Infrared microscopy, and/or electron microscopy.  It is now possible to observe crystallization behaviors that are directly related to conditions encountered in plastics manufacturing operations and relate bulk property development to direct microstructure evolution. Undergraduate researchers collaborated directly with industrial and academic partners and knowledge was communicated to engineers in the aerospace, automotive and medical industries to immediately influence part designs, yielding microstructure for optimized properties in strength, safety, and biodegradation.

Intellectual Merit:  Coupling the development of fast-calorimetry techniques with careful rheological and subsequent methods, this program evaluated a series of polymers with increasing backbone stiffness and enthalpic interactions, providing insight to the importance of chain architecture to drive the mechanism of flow-induced crystallization.  In many cases a flow-induced nematic phase was identified prior to flow induced crystallization, and the flow-induced structures displayed a thermal and shear stability beyond those observed in typical lamellar crystalline structures of the same polymer.

In addition to confirming our hypothesis that flow induced precursors developed under shear in the melt have sufficient stability to nucleate subsequent crystallization events, provided that the temperature of the melt does not exceed the equilibrium melting temperature, the program developed a working understanding of the thermodynamic and kinetic drivers that cause a polymer to preferentially form a specific type of crystalline phase or microstructure. Bulk properties are driven by microstructure that evolves with specific shear work, which means that the resulting polymer crystalline polymorph, lamellar thickness, and other microstructural characteristics change with melt flow history.  This is important because the properties of everyday items, from the simple plastic fork to the complex drug-eluting polymer stent used in heart surgery, are optimized though control of the shear flow energy and the resulting microstructure.  If this melt flow is not properly controlled, products can fail prematurely and potentially cause great harm in more advanced applications.

Oftentimes these advanced applications employ high-temperature engineering thermoplastic that contain fibers or other additives for property enhancement.  For example, many high-end bearings contain glass filled poly (ether ether keytone) (PEEK).  During this program PEEK was systematically investigated using the methods developed for unfilled polymers. In this work, found that the glass fiber plays a different role under quiescent and shearing conditions during the PEEK crystallization. The quiescent crystallization data collected by FSC suggest glass fiber slows down the crystallization of PEEK, whereas under shearing conditions, once the applied work exceeded the critical applied work, glass loading accelerates the crystallization of PEEK instead of slowing it down.  Ongoing research will help to elucidate the mechanism behind the acceleration; but the hypothesis is that glass fibers help to orient the polymer in a local shear field induced between the glass fiber and polymer surfaces.  To date, the most impactful result is perhaps the discovery of the sensitivity of polymers to different levels of shearing work across the entire melt temperature range was explained and a new method for evaluating shear-induced crystallization was introduced into the scientific community.

Broader Impacts: The program also supported our “Next Steps in Stem” program.  The annual programs were capped at ten students each year specifically so that our team could develop strong relationships and have a meaningful experience with each girl in attendance. Of the 36 students engaged during the four years of programming, 12 of these girls have elected to attend Penn State Behrend or another Penn State campus.  Fourteen of these students are yet to graduate high school, and so our final impacts are yet unknown.  In addition, ten REU students were supported and each went on to either graduate school or meaningful, related employment.  Ongoing discussions with commercial polymer melt processing simulation companies indicate the long-term commercial potential for the program results, and two industrially-sponsored research programs have already been funded to continue this work and facilitate rapid transfer of results to industrial processing.

por.por_txt_cntn:
Overview: The primary objective of this research program was to develop a step-change improvement in the understanding of flow-enhanced nucleation and crystallization in polymer melts in part through considering, for the first time, heating and cooling rates that are on the timescale of polymer processing (up to 5000 K/second). To date, the research has revealed crystallization behaviors previously undiscovered such as the mechanistic competition between flow and particulate-driven nucleation. 


Flash DSC (FSC) techniques allow rapid heating and cooling of polymers. The technique allows for direct thermal analysis, but also empowers polymer scientists to precisely control the crystallization pathway during solidification, and the resulting sample can be used for further analysis, essentially employing the FSC technique for both data acquisition as well as sample preparation. This research has enabled robust methods development that begins with controlled shear flow (rheology) followed by thermal conditioning at high heating/cooling rates (FSC), followed yet again by subsequent analysis using X-ray analysis, atomic force microscopy, FT-Infrared microscopy, and/or electron microscopy. It is now possible to observe crystallization behaviors that are directly related to conditions encountered in plastics manufacturing operations and relate bulk property development to direct microstructure evolution. Undergraduate researchers collaborated directly with industrial and academic partners and knowledge was communicated to engineers in the aerospace, automotive and medical industries to immediately influence part designs, yielding microstructure for optimized properties in strength, safety, and biodegradation.


Intellectual MERIT: Coupling the development of fast-calorimetry techniques with careful rheological and subsequent methods, this program evaluated a series of polymers with increasing backbone stiffness and enthalpic interactions, providing insight to the importance of chain architecture to drive the mechanism of flow-induced crystallization. In many cases a flow-induced nematic phase was identified prior to flow induced crystallization, and the flow-induced structures displayed a thermal and shear stability beyond those observed in typical lamellar crystalline structures of the same polymer.


In addition to confirming our hypothesis that flow induced precursors developed under shear in the melt have sufficient stability to nucleate subsequent crystallization events, provided that the temperature of the melt does not exceed the equilibrium melting temperature, the program developed a working understanding of the thermodynamic and kinetic drivers that cause a polymer to preferentially form a specific type of crystalline phase or microstructure. Bulk properties are driven by microstructure that evolves with specific shear work, which means that the resulting polymer crystalline polymorph, lamellar thickness, and other microstructural characteristics change with melt flow history. This is important because the properties of everyday items, from the simple plastic fork to the complex drug-eluting polymer stent used in heart surgery, are optimized though control of the shear flow energy and the resulting microstructure. If this melt flow is not properly controlled, products can fail prematurely and potentially cause great harm in more advanced applications.


Oftentimes these advanced applications employ high-temperature engineering thermoplastic that contain fibers or other additives for property enhancement. For example, many high-end bearings contain glass filled poly (ether ether keytone) (PEEK). During this program PEEK was systematically investigated using the methods developed for unfilled polymers. In this work, found that the glass fiber plays a different role under quiescent and shearing conditions during the PEEK crystallization. The quiescent crystallization data collected by FSC suggest glass fiber slows down the crystallization of PEEK, whereas under shearing conditions, once the applied work exceeded the critical applied work, glass loading accelerates the crystallization of PEEK instead of slowing it down. Ongoing research will help to elucidate the mechanism behind the acceleration; but the hypothesis is that glass fibers help to orient the polymer in a local shear field induced between the glass fiber and polymer surfaces. To date, the most impactful result is perhaps the discovery of the sensitivity of polymers to different levels of shearing work across the entire melt temperature range was explained and a new method for evaluating shear-induced crystallization was introduced into the scientific community.


broader IMPACTS: The program also supported our Next Steps in Stem program. The annual programs were capped at ten students each year specifically so that our team could develop strong relationships and have a meaningful experience with each girl in attendance. Of the 36 students engaged during the four years of programming, 12 of these girls have elected to attend Penn State Behrend or another Penn State campus. Fourteen of these students are yet to graduate high school, and so our final impacts are yet unknown. In addition, ten REU students were supported and each went on to either graduate school or meaningful, related employment. Ongoing discussions with commercial polymer melt processing simulation companies indicate the long-term commercial potential for the program results, and two industrially-sponsored research programs have already been funded to continue this work and facilitate rapid transfer of results to industrial processing.


					Last Modified: 12/05/2023

					Submitted by: AlicynMRhoades
